title: Blundering Bulgarian police coat themselves with pepper spray during protests

Bulgarian police were caught in a sting of their own after accidentally coating themselves in pepper spray during protests.

Cops attempting to disperse protesters in the capital Sofia did not take into account the wind direction when launching their pepper spray hoses.

When one officer tried to aim the mace at a group staging anti-government protests outside the Bulgarian parliament this weekend, him and his mates were left red faced and in pain when the wind sent it straight into their eyes.

The hilarious footage has since gone viral on social media, showing the group of policemen retreat and rinse their eyes out with water - particularly as it was considered a heavy-handed move for only a handful of demonstrators.

(Image: Twitter)

(Image: Twitter)

Polish TV station TVP Info report that the protesters had tried to block the street as they called for early parliamentary elections and respect for their country's democracy.

Bulgarian authorities have since stated that nobody was seriously hurt during the incident.

Jasper Neve, a Dutchman living in Bulgaria who posted the viral video explained: "Bulgaria is a peaceful country, where protests very rarely go more violent than a bit of pushing.

"This explains the inexperience of the police with things like pepper spray."
